b4e71eecc39ecf39d5104137bd8b21a5 (22:20): I'm trying to write a regular expression to match file locations in windows (eg C:\Somefile.ext). What's wrong with [a-zA-Z]:+.\w{3}?
58140e53c092a881064ead7d8633091f (22:21): omg i explodet the string by \n and forgot, that the \n is now missing
1d9212d435e6694d5f576ff16821421a (22:22): Concord_Dawn, that will miss some file names
1d9212d435e6694d5f576ff16821421a (22:23): Concord_Dawn, not extensions are 3 characters, and windows filenames can have -,_ spaces, and maybe other characters
b4e71eecc39ecf39d5104137bd8b21a5 (22:23): well, it's for reading playlist files.
b4e71eecc39ecf39d5104137bd8b21a5 (22:23): So I suppose that I'll only need to read 4 character extensions.
1d9212d435e6694d5f576ff16821421a (22:24): file.foobarbaz is still a valid windows filename, just slightly more uncommon

5579037a7fb9b97c1b9b86f9377aa48f (03:33): I've seen in some scripts before, say, a function like ob_start() they put an @ (at) symbol before hand. Does it make it manditory or something?
f482345be6a1666e25c329f9532e79e5 (03:34): grogoreo this is a bad practice
5579037a7fb9b97c1b9b86f9377aa48f (03:35): xshad, oh right. Could you tell me what it does, or where I could look it up.  Just out of interest and to understand other peoples scripts

16a79782b70a1bc91a5b74a9c71ac438 (03:35): [@] The PHP error control operator that suppresses errors (@foo()), see: http://php.net/operators.errorcontrol - Don't use it. Think I'm wrong? Ask me about "GO".
